title: Wednesday, 26th June 2019

That day low is its lowest in two decades I think.

BE11:24am

Australia, the problem, mostly.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Numis can summarise:

BE11:24am

The Australian economy is experiencing its slowest growth since 2009. The recent state elections in Victoria and NSW have lead to some hiatus in infrastructure spend. The Federal Election in May 2019 returned a business-friendly centre right party, but the release of major defence projects has been much lower than normal, impacting the Project Management business. The Property segment, which accounted for c.35% of AAP NFI in 2018, has seen a significant reduction in dwelling approvals. We now forecast a NFI decline in AAP of 12% (previously growth of 1%).

FATDAZ @red there were some decent names on offex Weetabix was one such but lots of spurious ventures too lol
BE11:25am

And Brexit. Always Brexit.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Mixed performance in other segments. Energy is still recovering, aided by a generally better oil and gas market backdrop. Consulting UK & Ireland is now being impacted by Brexit uncertainty on clients' investment decisions. Services UK & Netherlands has seen a soft Water segment, as expected, and subdued Health Safety and Risk business. Norway is trading in line. But North America has been impacted by the loss of a team in California, impacting full-year expectations.

BE11:25am

So:

Viking1 Morning all
red @ FATDAZshire pharma i think started there
FATDAZ @red :)
red yes lots of stuff under half a million with not a lot going on but fees being taken. i tried to shake a few into some deals but most wouldnt have it
BE11:26am

We lower our forecasts materially for the second time in nine months. Our organic net fee income assumptions for 2019-21 are now -3.9% [previously +2.5%], 2.6% [4.0%] and 3.3% [4.0%], compared to a medium-term aspiration of c.5% growth pa. Our Group operating margins are now 7.6% [previously 9.4%], 8.2% [9.9%] and 8.6% [10.2%] vs an ambition of double-digits.

11:26 am
BE11:27am

We adjust our PBT forecasts for the negative impact of IFRS16 of c.£0.5m pa [c.£1.4m reduction in lease rental costs - which we include in unallocated expenses - offset by a c.£1.9m increase in lease liability interest].

BE11:27am

2020 should benefit from the absence of £1.5m of re-branding costs taken above the line in 2019.

BE11:27am

Owing to the reduction in EBITDA and the related increase in net debt, we now forecast 2019 net debt of £93.4m [1.8x ND/EBITDA], which is likely to limit further bolt-on M&A in the short-term.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

And RBC.

BE11:28am

The new management team has established a sensible strategy to transform the business from an unfocused conglomerate into an internationally recognised environmental consultancy (with significantly less exposure to the more volatile energy markets), and we ultimately see significant potential to turn around the business. Today’s update underlines the vulnerability of the model to market volatility, but the majority of this looks more to do with timing than fundamental changes to underlying markets. However, given the cut to expectations this morning we think this potential is likely to be overlooked in the near term, albeit bid expectations are now likely to come back onto the table.

BE11:29am

And Liberum:

11:29 am
BE11:29am

We reduce 2019 AAP EBIT by 63% to £6.0m to reflect weak market conditions

There are three principal issues. The State elections in Victoria and NSW have resulted in a hiatus in infrastructure spend, which has negatively affected Corview. The federal election may have resulted in delays in major defence projects. The Australian Property market is weak with dwelling approvals down 20% yoy at April. There are grounds for some optimism given that Corview is integrating well, the Federal election in May resulted in a more business friendly centre right government and the interest rate was cut from 1.5% to 1.25% in June. The ERP will be introduced into parts of Australia in H2 (the rest in FY2020) and will results in some implementation costs which are reflected in our new estimates.

We reduce 2019 North American EBIT by 20% to £4.5m to reflect a team departure

We reduce our estimated EBIT for the FY by 20% to £4.5m solely due to the departure of a small team, who have taken some major accounts with them. However, the improvement expected in Q2 2019 has now materialised and management expect a recovery in H2.

BE11:29am

I think they're shop broker, BTW.

nightingale20201 morning
BE11:35am

Goldman:

VV75 Brenntag being accused of selling chemicals to the syrian government secretly
BE11:35am

Revenue in 1H19 is flat y/y but EBITDA is +7% y/y and operating profit is +25% y/y excluding IFRS 16 driven by strength in EAAA, Environment & Infrastructure and cost savings. This 1H19 performance implies a 1H/2H weighting to achieve FY19 company-compiled consensus EBITDA of 40%/60%. A second half weighting in EBITDA is usual for Wood but this year is exacerbated by wind awards won in 1H19 which will contribute to 2H19. The company reiterated its FY outlook (unchanged despite profit contributing disposals), its expectation of 5% y/y revenue growth and $60m of cost synergies; it expects to meet consensus FY19 EBITDA estimates.
Net debt (excluding IFRS 16) at the end of June is expected to be $1.6bn, in line with FY18 as profit growth and improving working capital dynamics are offset by the timing of dividend payments as well as the payment of known exceptionals, including cash outflows for legacy AFW contracts including Aegis. Wood continues to expect a modest reduction in absolute net debt levels excluding the impact of disposals for the year end. It reiterated its target for 1.5x ND/EBITDA (ex IFRS 16) and its disposal target of $200-300m

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Reassuring, in short.

BE11:37am

Less short, Morgan Stanley.

BE11:37am

We expect a modest positive market reaction to the Wood Group's trading update. Net debt was in-line with expectations – flat HoH – and margins are improving with the delivery of synergies. Further, the absence of negatives we think leaves the company on track to meet its unchanged FY19 guidance. Making progress. Wood Group's trading update provides, in our view, evidence of the company making progress toward its unchanged 2019 outlook. Further, net debt was flat from YE18 levels of $1.6bn (excluding IFRS 16 impact of $570m). With no major surprises, stable net debt and margins improving, we expect a modest positive reaction to the trading statement and no major changes to consensus 2019 estimates. Margin improving mainly through delivery of synergies. Revenue for 1H19 is expected to be flat vs 1H18 at $5.4bn (excluding JVs). EBITDA – before IFRS 16 – should be up 7% to ~$313m. Including the impact from IFRS 16, we estimate EBITDA for 1H19 is likely to be ~$395m. The like-for-like margin expansion is largely supported by the delivery of synergies. However, the company also highlights underlying margin improvements in its Asset Solutions EAAA and E&I divisions. 2019 outlook unchanged: Wood Group reiterated its FY19 outlook, expecting revenue growth of 5% – already reflected in consensus estimate of $10.6bn – and EBITDA in-line with the Street at $927m (including IFRS 16 impact of $170m). With flat revenue in 1H19, the company's guidance calls for ~10% YoY top-line growth in 2H and EBITDA of ~$532m (including IFRS 16 impact of ~$88m). The back-end loaded EBITDA reflects higher contribution of cost synergies in 2H, in addition to the business' normal seasonality. Stable net debt: 1H19 net debt excluding $570m of lease liabilities is expected to be flat vs FY18 at $1.6bn – in-line with Bloomberg consensus estimates. Guidance of a modest reduction in absolute net debt by the end of the year was also unchanged. Implied ND/EBITDA for 1H19 stands at 2.6x (1H18 at 2.7x) and 2.1x on FY19 EBITDA guidance.Working capital: No details until 1H19 results. However, the company highlights its debt position in 1H19 reflects active management of working capital, offset by the $159m dividend payment and cash outflows related to exceptional and contract provisions – already anticipated.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

As per Barclays;

BE11:43am

A sale of thyssenkrupp’s Elevator Technology division (tka ET) looks increasingly likely to us. In our view there is simply too much strategic value in elevator consolidation for management’s announced single-track IPO plan to be rational. Investors have asked us 3 key questions in regards to a potential acquisition by Kone of tka ET: What would a possible deal structure look like? Could Kone generate a positive return from an acquisition? And would Antti Herlin (who controls 62% of Kone voting rights) tolerate the level of dilution associated with a potential acquisition?

Bluesky21 Isn't Kone already #2 in the elevator sector?

All of which we covered back in May, when the idea last came up.

A Kone-Thyssenkrup Elevator merger deal could provide JEFe 0.8%-2.2% in cost
synergies on the combined entities' sales. On our estimates, this would equate to
€145m-€400m in cost savings worth €2.3bn-€6.4bn in enterprise value on a Kone 16x
EV/EBIT multiple. The value opportunity for Kone shareholders ultimately depends on
price paid vs synergy outcome – Exhibit 27 shows a range of possible outcomes
and what combination could turn out to be value-destructive or accretive for Kone shareholders. The analysis suggests that for a 1.5% cost synergy outcome, Kone
wouldcreate value for its shareholders only if it pays

Viking1 Does Krupp still own 18% of Thyssen
FATDAZ @excel in chrome browser tabs with stock info in the pages show the price tab header
11:48 am
BE11:48am

.... greater than 18.5x 2020 EV/EBIT. At this
multiple, Kone shareholders would have paid Thyssenkrup shareholders in full and
upfront for all the hard work Kone would need to undertake to realise the potential
synergies.

BE11:48am

Any deal is subject to high risks
We think the structure and likely outcome of any potential takeover or tie-up between
the two elevator giants will be much more complex than is currently perceived:
• Will be subject to country-level labour union agreements.
• Regional antitrust scrutiny/issues will also likely delay but also complicate the
structure. Not ideal for cash-strapped TKA. The elevator and escalator market in
Europe, in particular, is highly concentrated.
• From an antitrust standpoint, a TKA ET merger with Schindler would be even more
challenging given stronger geographical/business overlap in the US/EMEA.

BE11:49am

Size matters in this industry…
A combined entity would be c.45% larger than Otis, the largest of the Top 4 today. Kone
andTKA ET geographically complement each other: TKA has higher sales exposure to
the US vs Kone lowest of the Top 4. In China, Kone is the number one player while TKA
holds the lowest share. Kone is also much stronger in EMEA than TKA (holds

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Jupiter’s flows look to have stabilised, although some of the larger funds are still declining and investment performance relatively mixed. Nevertheless, we upgrade our forecasts (by 11%), driven by higher performance fee expectations and AuM assumptions. We now see the balance of risk shifting towards the upside and move to Buy (from Hold), in contrast to the current consensus recommendation of Sell/Hold.

Jupiter Fund Management PLC (JUP:LSE): Last: 423.00, up 11 (+2.67%), High: 423.50, Low: 416.90, Volume: 2.45m
BornCynic Thanks BE
BE11:59am

Clearly the overall backdrop has been challenging, with more volatile equity market conditions and certain strategies out of favour. Looking at three-year investment performance against the funds’ respective benchmarks, we find a relatively mixed picture. There has been strong performance by the European funds, but weaker performance from some of the UK funds with a value bias. Whilst the Merlin funds have delivered good performance, we remain more cautious on the asset-gathering ability given the level of competition in this sector and the relatively high fees that Merlin charges.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

After a period of relative underperformance, Jupiter’s shares have recovered somewhat since the start of the year. Today, the shares do not look particularly expensive, trading on a December 2019 EV/EBIT of 10x. Jupiter continues to deliver a high quality of earnings, operating margins remain attractive and the dividend yield stands at 5.7%. It might be slightly early in calling the turn in flows but the balance of risk has definitely shifted to the upside. We arrive at a target price of 480p (from 375p), and move to Buy from Hold.

Bluesky21 Jupiter AUM was £37.0bn at 16Q2, £40.5bn at 16Q4. Brexit referendum in late Jun-16 did not do it much damage
